alert.note: Alert for Santa Barbara; Ventura (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued December 20 at 10:38PM PST until December 21 at 12:30AM PST by NWS Oxnard
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1230 AM PST THURSDAY FOR SOUTHEASTERN SANTA BARBARA AND WESTERN VENTURA COUNTIES... At 1038 PM PST, Radar and rain gauge reports indicated heavy rain falling across the warned area. Between 3 and 7 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 0.75 to 1 inch in 1 hour. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. HAZARD...Heavy rain will produce possible life threatening flash flooding. SOURCE...Gauges reported. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. Large rocks and boulders may fall onto roadways and into areas below steep terrain. Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... West Ventura, East Santa Barbara, Montecito, Carpinteria, La Conchita, Rincon Point, Summerland, Rose Valley, Old Man Mountain, Lake Casitas, Meiners Oaks, Highway 33 between Wheeler Springs and Rose Valley Road, Seacliff, Solimar Beach and Reyes Peak. The gauges at La Granada Mountain in western Ventura County and Doulton Tunnel recorded about 0.50 inch in around 10 minutes. The gauge at Doulton Tunnel in eastern Santa Barbara County also recorded an inch of rain in 28 minutes and almost 1.50 inches in an hour. FLASH FLOOD...GAUGE INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE EXPECTED RAINFALL RATE...0.75-1 INCH IN 1 HOUR
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
